intro: Hemionitis geraniifolia, commonly known as the golden ragwort, is a small, perennial herb native to the western United States. It is characterized by its basal rosette of narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces yellow flowers in late spring to early summer, which are clustered in dense, elongated inflorescences. It thrives in dry, rocky soils and is often found in open woodlands and grasslands. Hemionitis geraniifolia is a member of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is known for its medicinal properties in traditional uses.
